==Ethics in non-human animal societies==
 
==Ethics in non-human animal societies==
    −
In the social behaviour of nonhuman animals (especially mammals) and in the evolutionary theory that explains such behaviour, we may find some origins of human morality or ethics. Like humans, social animals maybe have in ways characteristics of what we call altruism :
+
In the social behaviour of nonhuman animals (especially mammals) and in the evolutionary theory that explains such behaviour, we may find some origins of human morality or ethics. Like humans, social animals maybe have in ways characteristics of what we call [[altruism]] :
     
*Dolphins support sick or injured animals, swimming under them for hours at a time and pushing them to the surface so they can breathe,
 
*Dolphins support sick or injured animals, swimming under them for hours at a time and pushing them to the surface so they can breathe,
Line 171: Line 171:  
*A monkey will present its back to another monkey, who will pick out parasites; after a time the roles will be reversed (case of altruism of reciprocity.
 
*A monkey will present its back to another monkey, who will pick out parasites; after a time the roles will be reversed (case of altruism of reciprocity.
    −
In this perpective, it seems likely that morality is the gradual outgrowth of forms of altruism that exist in some social animals and that are the result of the usual evolutionary processes of natural selection. No myths are required to explain its existence.
+
In this perpective, it seems likely that [[morality]] is the gradual outgrowth of forms of [[altruism]] that exist in some social animals and that are the result of the usual evolutionary processes of [[natural selection]]. No myths are required to explain its existence.
